vctk/wav16/p336/p336_021.wav|p336|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.

vctk/wav16/s5/s5_012.wav|s5|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways. 
vctk/wav16/s5/s5_013.wav|s5|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation. 
vctk/wav16/s5/s5_014.wav|s5|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods. 
vctk/wav16/s5/s5_015.wav|s5|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain. 
vctk/wav16/s5/s5_016.wav|s5|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky. 
vctk/wav16/s5/s5_017.wav|s5|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically. 
vctk/wav16/s5/s5_018.wav|s5|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain. 
vctk/wav16/s5/s5_019.wav|s5|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows. 
vctk/wav16/s5/s5_020.wav|s5|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed. 
vctk/wav16/s5/s5_021.wav|s5|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases. 
vctk/wav16/s5/s5_022.wav|s5|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows. 
vctk/wav16/s5/s5_023.wav|s5|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
